Award.AwardTitle: Geometry and arithmetic of locally symmetric spaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
Arithmetic lattices in semisimple Lie groups are fundamental mathematical objects that have deep significance in geometry, topology, group theory, and number theory. This project considers the way in which these fields interact, particularly the effect on the geometry of locally symmetric spaces. More specifically, the PI will apply insights from number theory, group theory, algebraic geometry, and low dimensional topology to study the geometric and topological properties of arithmetic locally symmetric spaces. Special focus will be placed on lattices acting on real and complex hyperbolic space, where a better understanding of arithmetic lattices can shed light on several open questions about the geometry and topology of finite volume real and complex hyperbolic manifolds. Many well-known properties of 2 and 3-dimensional hyperbolic manifolds lead to analogous questions in higher dimensions, and it is of significant interest to study which of these properties are peculiar to low dimensions and which remain true for the more enigmatic higher-dimensional spaces.

Geometry and number theory are two of the most classical areas of mathematical study, and the interaction between the two has fascinated mathematicians since ancient times. This relationship lies behind countless great mathematical advances from Euclid's Elements to Gauss to Wiles's proof of Fermat's Last Theorem. Studying this interplay continues to bear deep fruit. Number fields are objects related to solutions to polynomial equations with integer coefficients (e.g., the rational numbers), and number fields give rise to an infinite family of geometric objects called arithmetic locally symmetric spaces, which lie at the heart of the Langlands program and often parameterize fundamental objects in mathematics and physics. Invariants of these number fields, like the discriminant of a polynomial, and properties of associated symmetry groups lead to deep insight about nature of these geometric spaces. Group theory is one of the most significant assets in the modern study of geometry and number theory, which goes back to Lagrange and Galois's study of the roots of polynomials and their symmetry, and the modern viewpoint originates in Klein's Erlangen program from the 1870s. Recent years have also seen significant applications of the geometry of arithmetic locally symmetric spaces to computer science, information theory, graph theory, and cryptography, and the connections with number theory and group theory are central to many of these applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project made a number of advances in our understanding of the geometry and topology of locally symmetric spaces, particularly those with an intimate connection to number theory and algebraic geometry. Locally symmetric spaces have the important property that they "look the same" everywhere; for example, the inside of a perfectly flat square is locally symmetric, but the surface of the Earth is not because of its varying topography. In classical geometry, one classifies shapes and spaces by invariants, and this project broadly studied locally symmetric spaces by studying the behavior of various invariants. For example, knowing two angles determines the similarity class of a triangle, and knowing the areas of two similar triangles suffices to determine whether or not they are congruent; thus we have a satisfying classification of triangles by their invariants.

In Thurston's revolutionary program for understanding 3-dimensional geometry and topology, the spaces that proved most critical are the hyperbolic 3-manifolds, meaning that every 2-dimensional plane through every point looks like the surface of a saddle, rather than a flat plane or the round surface of a sphere. Hyperbolic manifolds are fundamental examples of negatively curved locally symmetric spaces. As in classical Euclidean geometry, area is an important invariant in hyperbolic geometry, and a significant achievement of the past 30 years is the recent complete classification of the smallest volume hyperbolic 3-manifolds (unlike in Euclidean geometry, volumes of hyperbolic manifolds are bounded away from zero).

This project made significant progress on classification of small volume locally symmetric spaces in dimension four. The spaces considered during this project were the generalizations of hyperbolic space with the closest connections with algebraic geometry: those modeled on either (1) the product of hyperbolic planes or (2) the complex hyperbolic plane. In both cases, significant strides were made toward the classification of the smallest volume manifolds, and the spaces considered end up being "arithmetic", meaning that they have deep ties to number theory. Consequently, deep methods from number theory and algebraic geometry are available for both achieving the classification and for deriving geometric and topological properties of these spaces. Going the other direction, these results provide important new classification theorems in algebraic geometry.

Another important aspect of Thurston's program is that it leads to explicit constructions of hyperbolic 3-manifolds. Moreover, Agol's recent solution to Thurston's virtual fiber question says that, up to a complete understanding of symmetry groups of hyperbolic 3-manifolds, Thurston's construction allows one to classify all 3-dimensional spaces. The classification problems studied during this project also led to a number of completely explicit constructions of complex hyperbolic manifolds, some of which are quite analogous to Thurston's fibration construction. Moreover, these hands-on methods allowed this project to explore new geometric and topological phenomena, give new understanding of the behavior of invariants of these spaces, and open many new doors for future research in the area via deeper understanding of explicit examples.

Another independent direction studied during this project was the question of how much one can understand about a space given enough information about geometric sub-objects. For example, one completely understands a triangle given the lengths of its sides. This project showed that an analogous statement for n-dimensional hyperbolic manifolds is false, and other work finds new finiteness phenomena for locally symmetric subspaces of certain spaces that are important for the Langlands program in number theory.

Finally, this project studied "deformations" of geometric structures, which are akin to taking a "family" of rectangles where the side lengths change in a continuous manner. For example Thurston showed that an operation called "Dehn surgery" on most knots in 3-space leads to an infinite family of hyperbolic 3-manifolds that are arranged nicely into a deformation space of geometric structures on the ambient space around the knot. Using powerful tools from arithmetic geometry, work done during this project associated a so-called Azumaya algebra to this deformation space, which one can consider as a new knot invariant. This has a number of applications to studying the invariants of these 3-manifolds and raises a number of questions for future research, like how and whether similar invariants can be defined for other deformation spaces.
